Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research on the Marchantiophyta, Anthocerophyta and Bryophyta of the Cape Horn Archipelago: Floristics and Implications for Conservation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research on the Marchantiophyta, Anthocerophyta and Bryophyta of the Cape Horn Archipelago: Floristics and Implications for Conservation

The Cape Horn Archipelago in southernmost Chile is poorly known biologically because of its inaccessibility. Mosses, liverworts and hornworts (i.e., bryophytes), although small plants, comprise the majority of plant biodiversity in this remote region. This project proposes to inventory the bryophytes of the area and prepare a manual for their identification. Exploration will be carried out through the use of a rented ship to take the organizers, W. R. Buck and J. J. Engel, and their collaborators from island to island to collect. The data will also be used to collaborate on conservation of the region.

Many of the bryophytes of the Cape Horn Archipelago are otherwise only found in distant regions, especially New Zealand and northern North America. This study will allow better understanding of the distribution of these plants and how they have come to grow where they are. A local project, ?Ecotourism with a Hand-Lens,? teaches students and tour-operators to include bryophytes in tourism, thereby using these plants to assist the local economy. The information on diversity and distribution of bryophytes will be useful in determining which areas deserve protection and which can be developed. The project collaborates closely with outreach programs at the Field Museum and will contribute to improving science instruction and student learning at a major urban school system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cape Horn Archipelago, at the southernmost tip of South America in Chile, is one of the most remote areas of the world. Although there has been exploration in the region since the 17th century, very little is known about the bryophytes (mosses, liverworts and hornworts) of the area. In the era of exploring ships, most expeditions passing through this area either went north through the Straits of Magellan or south nearer Antarctica to avoid treacherous, rocky shoals and strong winds. A climate of cool temperatures, abundant precipitation and strong winds have resulted in the Cape Horn Archipelago being a “hotspot” for bryophytes. Even though the region occupies less than 0.01% of the Earth’s land, it hosts more than 5% of the known bryophytes. The area is scenically spectacular, with virgin southern beech (Nothofagus) forests, their trunks sheathed with mosses and lichens, and glaciers coming down to the sea. We explored the region by renting a commercial crabbing ship each of the four years of the project. We divided the region into quadrants and extensively explored one each year, during the austral summer (late November to early March). Each of the 8–10 bryologists on board collected hundreds of specimens. We transformed the ship into an efficient bryophyte-collecting vessel. The hold was made into a drying room, using wood and wire racks above light bulbs and fans, ideal for drying the paper bags and packets used to collect bryophytes. The galley was often turned into a high-tech laboratory, with microscopes, cameras and computers. This equipment was to document an important character for the identification of liverworts. Liverworts have a unique cellular organelle, oil bodies, that are useful taxonomically, but which disappear once the plants are dead. So, if one doesn’t document these structures within a short time of collection, the information is lost forever.

 

A core of bryologists, American and Chilean, participated each year, with other bryologists chosen based on their expertise. We have discovered many species new to the region. However, the very nature of the region limited us to mostly collecting along coastal regions. Interiors of islands were difficult to access, with no trails and steep slopes. We were able to collect in a few remote areas. Once we had an opportunity to collect near a glacier that was not coastal by renting horses from a local ranch, who also provided a guide for the 4 hour ride each way. In the final year of the project, two of the younger participants were able to backpack into the interior of Isla Navarino and collect at high elevations. Although we only collected a small percentage of the area, we were able to find almost all the bryophytes there. Each year the number of previously uncollected species decreased until the final years only a handful were found new to the region. Although most species collected were previously known from the region, we needed to know the local distribution of the species and so collected every species on every island. There is a strong precipitation gradient in the region. The westernmost part of our area receives about 4 meters (12 feet) of rain a year, but the eastern end only about 700 millimeters (2 feet). The wetter area has a larger liverwort flora whereas the drier area is more diverse for mosses, and we wanted to document how and where this change took place. As taxonomic work continues, we predict that the total number of bryophytes will be about 500, about half mosses and half liverworts/hornworts. In addition to collecting bryophytes for our own research, we were able to aid other botanists. Lichens collected on the trip have resulted in several species new to science as well as species new to the region. A botanist on one trip documented the flowering plants.
